metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

question: Summarise what topics are covered across all first-year chemistry modules.
answer:
Based on the provided context, first-year chemistry modules cover topics such as:

* Atoms, molecules, matter (CHEM1102)
* Chemical bonding, molecular self-organization, chemical kinetics, organic synthesis, medicinal chemistry, molecular symmetry, organometallic chemistry, solid-state inorganic chemistry, analytical chemistry, and atmospheric chemistry (CHEM3302)

These modules provide an introduction to interdisciplinary and applied chemistry, covering a range of scientific studies underpinned by chemistry and its applications in today's society and industry.

retrieved_docs.snippet: The module comprises a selection of topics in interdisciplinary and applied chemistry (of which students must choose two to be examined). Students will gain an appreciation of the wide range of scientific studies underpinned by chemistry and fields where the subject is applied in todayâ€™s society and industry. The examined topics will require students to demonstrate higher-level understanding of topics in interdisciplinary and applied chemistry, and solve unseen problems of a level

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide an overview of some areas of current chemical research, including in the area of sustainability, and of ethical issues surrounding science. Students will develop skills in identifying and reading scientific literature, and in presenting science in different formats and for different audiences. Students will develop other transferrable skills including coding and self-reflection. 
Objectives

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide an overview of some areas of current chemical research, including in the area of sustainability, and of ethical issues surrounding science. Students will develop skills in identifying and reading scientific literature, and in presenting science in different formats and for different audiences. Students will develop other transferrable skills including coding and self-reflection. 
Objectives

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide a concise introduction to modern chemistry with an initial focus on a qualitative appreciation of electronic structure and how it determines the chemical and structural properties of matter. The module will then provide an introduction to chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, organic structures and mechanisms, and the chemistry of transition metal-ligand complexes. 
Objectives

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This 10-credit module in semester 1 shows how the objects around us are derived from incredibly small things that we cannot even see, but are absolutely fundamental to modern science. The module gives an introduction to the structure and bonding in atoms and molecules, salts and metals. It also looks at atomic structure and properties as a basis for systematic chemistry of the elements.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide students with the skills to interpret nuclear magnetic resonance and mass spectra to determine structures of small molecules. The module will also provide a theoretical basis for quantitative and qualitative analytical chemistry, in particular analysis by chromatographic methods such as gas chromatography and high-performance liquid chromatography.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
The module will also provide students with an understanding of energy levels and quantum chemistry. 
Objectives

 On completion of this module students should be able to: - Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of inorganic solid state chemistry, quantum mechanics and spectroscopy to solve chemical problems. - Apply mathematical skills to solve problems in inorganic solid state chemistry, quantum mechanics and spectroscopy.
 
 
 
Learning outcomes

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet: The module comprises a compulsory 5-credit topic on theoretical and computational chemistry (assessed via coursework), and a selection of topics in fundamental chemistry (of which students must choose one to be examined).On completion of the compulsory topic, students will be able to:- describe the general methods used to solve the many electron Schrodinger equations for a molecule;- apply ab-initio computational methods to solve electronic structure problems for molecules;The examined topics

question: How do you know which modules are second-year modules?
answer: According to the provided context, second-year modules are those that have "Year: 2" specified in their overview. For example, CHEM2112 has "Year: 2", indicating it is a second-year module. Additionally, some modules specify pre-requisites as "Level 2 in Chemistry or Level 2 in Joint Honours (Science) with Chemistry or equivalent", which also suggests they are second-year modules.

question: How many second-year modules are available?
answer:
Based on the provided context, there are **4** second-year modules available:

1. CHEM2112: Chemistry of Materials: what they are and how we know (10 credits)
2. CHEM2331: TBC at the start of the academic year
3. CHEM3226: TBC (module summary not provided)
4. CHEM2690: Laboratory Work 2e (20 credits)

Note that CHEM2492 and CHEM8501 are not second-year modules, as they have different credit values and pre-requisites.

question: Summarise what topics are covered across all first-year chemistry modules.
answer:

Note that there are no specific topics listed for the other modules (CHEM3291, CHEM3292) as they seem to be interdisciplinary and applied chemistry modules that allow students to choose from a range of topics.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide an overview of some areas of current chemical research, including in the area of sustainability, and of ethical issues surrounding science. Students will develop skills in identifying and reading scientific literature, and in presenting science in different formats and for different audiences. Students will develop other transferrable skills including coding and self-reflection. 
Objectives

answer:
After reviewing the provided module information, I found that there are no modules specifically about nanotechnology. However, some modules may touch on related topics such as chemistry of materials, solid-state chemistry, or spectroscopy.

If you're looking for modules with a focus on materials science or nanotechnology, I don't know if any specific modules in the provided list cover these topics directly.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide an overview of some areas of current chemical research, including in the area of sustainability, and of ethical issues surrounding science. Students will develop skills in identifying and reading scientific literature, and in presenting science in different formats and for different audiences. Students will develop other transferrable skills including coding and self-reflection.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide a concise introduction to modern chemistry with an initial focus on a qualitative appreciation of electronic structure and how it determines the chemical and structural properties of matter. The module will then provide an introduction to chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, organic structures and mechanisms, and the chemistry of transition metal-ligand complexes. 
Objectives

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This 10-credit module in semester 1 shows how the objects around us are derived from incredibly small things that we cannot even see, but are absolutely fundamental to modern science. The module gives an introduction to the structure and bonding in atoms and molecules, salts and metals. It also looks at atomic structure and properties as a basis for systematic chemistry of the elements.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
Module summary
This module will provide students with the skills to interpret nuclear magnetic resonance and mass spectra to determine structures of small molecules. The module will also provide a theoretical basis for quantitative and qualitative analytical chemistry, in particular analysis by chromatographic methods such as gas chromatography and high-performance liquid chromatography.

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet:
The module will also provide students with an understanding of energy levels and quantum chemistry. 
Objectives

 On completion of this module students should be able to: - Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of inorganic solid state chemistry, quantum mechanics and spectroscopy to solve chemical problems. - Apply mathematical skills to solve problems in inorganic solid state chemistry, quantum mechanics and spectroscopy.
 
 
 
Learning outcomes

metadata.title: Undergraduate module Catalogue : Module and Programme Catalogue

retrieved_docs.snippet: The module comprises a compulsory 5-credit topic on theoretical and computational chemistry (assessed via coursework), and a selection of topics in fundamental chemistry (of which students must choose one to be examined).On completion of the compulsory topic, students will be able to:- describe the general methods used to solve the many electron Schrodinger equations for a molecule;- apply ab-initio computational methods to solve electronic structure problems for molecules;The examined topics

question: Summarise what topics are covered across all first-year chemistry modules.
answer:
Here's a summary of the topics covered across all first-year chemistry modules:

• Atoms, molecules, matter (CHEM1102)
• Chemical bonding (CHEM3302)
• Molecular self-organization (CHEM3302)
• Chemical kinetics (CHEM3302)

Note that these are just some of the topics mentioned in the module descriptions and may not be an exhaustive list.

question: How do you know which modules are second-year modules?
answer:
Here's how you can identify second-year modules:

• Check the "Year" field in the module catalog entry. If it says "2", it's a second-year module.
• Look for modules with pre-requisites that mention "Level 1 of a Chemistry or Materials science programme similar to that at Leeds, or equivalent". This typically indicates a second-year module.
• Some modules may explicitly state that they are only available to students in their second year.
